docs.lead_paragraph: On the first day of Congressional debate on the Republicans' vast umbrella budget legislation that at a stroke would overhaul decades of Government social policy, Republican senators managed today to preserve their plan to place strict limits on Medicare spending while avoiding, at least for the time being, a direct vote on the matter. Democratic senators had hoped to force a separate vote on the Medicare part of the huge legislation, and so use that vote against Republicans in the next election. When they proved unable to do so, they were irate.

headline.main: G.O.P. Avoids Senate Vote on Medicare

docs.lead_paragraph: The prospects for broad financial deregulation this year dimmed considerably today as House Republic leaders abandoned a proposal for a $4.8 billion fee on three Government-sponsored businesses that assist the housing industry. Representative Jim Leach, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the House Banking Committee, emerged tonight from a meeting with Speaker Newt Gingrich to say that his proposal was "no longer an optism."

headline.main: Prospects Fading in House For Repeal of Glass-Steagall

docs.lead_paragraph: The House is scheduled to vote today on a remarkably sensible, though tough, budget plan sponsored by Democrats, mostly conservative. The plan will not pass, but the vote still matters. President Clinton is likely to veto the initial budget that the Republican-controlled Congress puts on his desk. His negotiating strength will flow from today's vote. If Democrats line up behind their colleagues' plan, then Mr. Clinton can pull the G.O.P. toward its provisions. But if the Democrats flee, then he is left with no option to fight for. The Democrats' plan meets the stringent Republican test of balancing the budget within seven years. But the Democrats would more fairly spread the burden. Gone is the G.O.P.'s $245 billion tax cut that largely benefits upper-income families. That allows the Democrats to propose spending cuts 25 percent less severe than the harsh reductions proposed by the Republicans. Gone is the G.O.P.'s tax hike on the earnings of low-paid workers and the reduction in student loans. Also gone are Republican proposals to eliminate 60-year-old Federal entitlements for health insurance and cash assistance.

headline.main: A Budget Democrats Should Vote For

docs.lead_paragraph: Equifax Inc. said yesterday that it had named Daniel W. McGlaughlin, now president and chief operating officer, to replace C. B. Rogers Jr. as chief executive, effective on Jan. 1. The company, based in Atlanta, also reported a dividend increase as well as a planned stock split, antitakeover defense and a stock buyback. Equifax said Mr. Rogers, 66, would remain as chairman. Mr. McGlaughlin, 59, will retain the title of president. The position of chief operating officer will not be filled. Equifax, a provider of information to insurance, financial and health care companies, said it decided to raise its dividend 6.5 percent and repurchase up to $200 million of its shares. The company said its regular quarterly dividend would be increased to 16.5 cents a share from 15.5 cents. The company said its shareholder rights plan -- also called an antitakeover defense -- would be enacted if an unwanted suitor acquired a stake in the company of 20 percent or more.

headline.main: EQUIFAX PICKS CHIEF AND LIFTS DIVIDEND

docs.lead_paragraph: As Congress takes up the budget, the American public fears plans of the Republicans to curb Medicare spending, scoffs at their tax cut and flatly does not believe that the plan would produce a balanced budget by 2002, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows. By a nearly 3-to-1 margin, the public rejects the tax cuts that Senate Democrats spent the day denouncing. And by a 2-to-1 ratio, the public disapproves of the Republicans' Medicare plan, while conceding that it does not know much about it.

headline.main: AMERICANS REJECT BIG MEDICARE CUTS, A NEW POLL FINDS

docs.lead_paragraph: Starting Wednesday, Congress will begin voting on the huge budget bills that will give Republicans the chance to prove they mean their promises to change the way Government works -- most of all by balancing the Federal budget by the year 2002. Until this week, action on the budget has consisted of high-sounding resolutions, the defeat of a constitutional amendment requiring balance and energetic but inconclusive efforts to reduce the level of spending in the annual bills that finance Government agencies. Only 3 of those 13 measures have made their way to the White House.

headline.main: CONGRESS TO OPEN BUDGET BILL VOTES FOR 1996 SPENDING

docs.lead_paragraph: Remember WIN buttons? Those relics of the mid-1970's, with their "Whip Inflation Now" slogan avidly promoted by President Gerald R. Ford, are collector items today, reminders of a misty past that apparently shows no signs of returning. Indeed, the United States has just gone through five consecutive years of the lowest level of consumer price inflation since the economy's golden run in the mid-1960's.

docs.lead_paragraph: The mammoth budget bills before the Senate and the House of Representatives this week follow the same themes, although they differ somewhat on the margins. These are the main elements: TAXES Taxes would be reduced by $245 billion over seven years. Most families would get a tax cut of $500 a child. The tax rate on capital gains would be lowered, eligibility for individual retirement accounts would be expanded, the marriage tax penalty would be lessened and a tax credit would be allowed to offset some adoption expenses. The Senate would allow a tax credit for part of the interest on student loans. The House would abolish the alternative minimum tax.
